Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC: Center for Advanced Forestry Systems University of Georgia Site Phase II
Award.AbstractNarration:
In Phase II operation, the University of Maine Site of the I/UCRC for Advanced Forestry Systems (CAFS) intends to focus its research portfolio so as to advance understanding of plantation growth dynamics and yield and product quality impacts of forest management activities. Many of the problems and opportunities facing the management of forests today bridge disciplinary and regional boundaries. For technological advances to be made, it is necessary to approach research questions on multiple spatial and temporal scales, including the molecular, cellular, individual-tree, stand, and ecosystem levels. CAFS has been successful at providing the administrative structure and funding that has allowed scientists from these existing cooperatives to initiate much need cross-disciplinary research in areas of genetics, site manipulation, and growth and yield modeling.

Research conducted by the University of Georgia site of CAFS is targeted at increasing the competitiveness of forest products industries and forest landowners. Technology transfer between CAFS scientists and industry and government member personnel fosters rapid implementation of new technologies. Students trained via CAFS research are unique in the forestry sciences because of their applied problem-solving skills using interdisciplinary techniques across multiple scales. Aggressive recruiting for graduate students among under-represented groups will continue to be conducted, increasing the diversity of the workforce for both academia and industry in this traditionally diversity-deficient discipline. Opportunities will continue to be sought to involve undergraduate students in CAFS research activities, exposing them to the excitement of forest science and encouraging them to pursue graduate education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project allowed the center to improve existing knowledge about the expected value gain further when performing interventions in the forest, like removing trees halfway into a forest plantation cycle.  Also, the projects embraced during phase II, allowed the evaluation of the impact to fertilize trees at mid-rotation to improve the final volume and the effect of removing competing vegetation. Trials installed to investigate these matters, as well as the data collected over all these years, have helped the development of silvicultural tools (like prediction models implemented in software). At the same time, they were tools developed to see the impact of improved genetics in the final yield outcome of a forest plantation. Again, these tools implemented as growth and yield equations permitted center members to make better decisions concerning genotype plantation. One big step taken by the group is the exploration and implementation of contemporary statistical tools in the definition of models that guarantee a better way to perform a financial analysis of the results from this research. In specific, the ability to evaluate model uncertainty allowed the center a better framework to assess the risk of silviculture investment. These tools include models with explicit projection uncertainty, models with explicit spatial uncertainty and models that combine both to reduce overall uncertainty fostering better decisions.Another important outcome is on the industry side, where tools to assess defects in the lumber using non-destructive methods allowed the center to reduce the cost of evaluation defect evaluation. These tools used state of the art machine learning techniques, specially tailored to be implemented by mills participating in this study.
